## Problem 1
We calculate $\bar{\Phi}(z) \frac{z}{\phi(z)}$.
$$
\begin{aligned}
\bar{\Phi}(z) \frac{z}{\phi(z)} 
& =\int_z^{\infty} z e^{-x^2 / 2+z^2 / 2} d x=\int_z^{\infty} z e^{-(x-z)(x+z) / 2} d x \\
& =\int_0^{\infty} z e^{-u(u+2 z) / 2} d u\quad (\text{take } u=x-z)\\
& = \int_0^{\infty} z e^{-t} \frac{t}{\sqrt{2 t+z^2}} dt \quad (\text{take } u(u+2z)=2t)\\
& = \int_0^{\infty} \frac{1}{m} e^{-t} \frac{t}{\sqrt{2 t+1/m^2}} dt \quad (\text{take } z=\frac{1}{m})\\ 
& = \int_0^{\infty}  e^{-t} \frac{t}{\sqrt{2 t m^2+1}} dt 
\end{aligned}
$$
We define
$$
h(m,t) =  \left\{
\begin{array}{r} e^{-t} \frac{t}{\sqrt{2 t m^2+1}}, &t\geq0\\
0, &t<0
\end{array}   \right.

$$
It's obvious that, $\forall m,t \in \mathbb{R}$
$$
|h(m,t)| \leq g(t) = te^{-t}\mathbb{I}(t\geq0)
$$
and
$$
\int_{-\infty}^{+\infty} g(t) < \infty
$$
Therefore, by Dominated Convergence Theorem
$$
\begin{aligned}
\lim_{z \to +\infty} \bar{\Phi}(z) \frac{z}{\phi(z)}  &= \lim_{m \to 0} \int_0^{\infty}  e^{-t} \frac{t}{\sqrt{2 t m^2+1}} dt  \\
&= \int_0^{\infty} \lim_{m \to 0}  e^{-t} \frac{t}{\sqrt{2 t m^2+1}} dt  \\
&=\int_0^{\infty}te^{-t} dt\\
&=1
\end{aligned}
$$
Therefore,
$$
\bar{\Phi}(z) \sim \frac{\phi(z)}{z}, \quad \text { as } z \rightarrow \infty
$$
